frontmatter.title: Patch Locale of a Spectral Locale in Univalent Type Theory
Note on order theory terminology in UF

mainmatter.p: In this note, I briefly summarize some discussions that I (Ayberk Tosun) have had with Tom de Jong and Mart√≠n Escard√≥ and present my proposal for changes to terminology in order theory in univalent

Similar terminology is used in
the work de Jong and Escard√≥ on order theory in univalent foundations; and
the work of Tosun and Escard√≥ on locale theory in univalent foundations.
Let us first review the two most fundamental notions in the aforementioned lines of research respectively.
In de Jong's thesis, we have the notion of a \mathcal{V}-dcpo.
Let \mathcal{V} be a universe. A poset D is a \mathcal{V}-dcpo if the join of of every \mathcal{V}-family on set D exists in D.

mainmatter.p: Whereas in the MFPS paper of Tosun and Escard√≥, we have the notion of a ( \mathcal{U} , \mathcal{V} , \mathcal{W} )-frame.

A ( \mathcal{U} , \mathcal{V} , \mathcal{W} )-frame L consists of a
a type |L| : \mathcal{U}
a partial order - \le - : |L| \to |L| \to \Omega _{ \mathcal{V} },
a top element \mathbf{1} : |L|,
an operation - \wedge - : |L| \to |L| \to |L| giving the greatest lower bound U \wedge V of any two U, V : |L|.
an operation \bigvee - : \mathsf{Fam} _{ \mathcal{W} }(|L|) \to |L| giving the least upper bound \bigvee _{i : I} U_i of any \mathcal{W}-family \left \{ U_i \right \} _{i : I}.
such that binary meets distribute over arbitrary joins, i.e. U \wedge \bigvee _{i : I} V_i = \bigvee _{i : I} U \wedge V_i for every U : |L| and \mathcal{W}-family \{ V_i \} _{i : I} in |L|.

Most locales that come up in practice are defined by ( \mathcal{U} ^+, \mathcal{U} , \mathcal{U} )-frames, so this much generality is rarely needed. Such locales are called large and locally small.
A locale X is called large and locally small if it is given by a ( \mathcal{U} ^+, \mathcal{U} , \mathcal{U} )-frame.

In both domain theory and locale theory, some notion of basis is needed. In our previous work with Mart√≠n on locale theory, we used the following notion of small basis.

frontmatter.title: Small basis for a (U, V, W)-locale

mainmatter.p:
Let X be a ( \mathcal{U} , \mathcal{V} , \mathcal{W} )-locale. A basis for X is a \mathcal{W}-family (B, \beta ) on \mathcal{O} ( X ) satisfying the following conditions.
For every open U : \mathcal{O} ( X ), there is a \mathcal{W}-family (K_U, \kappa _U) on the basis index B, satisfying U = \bigvee _{k : K_U} \beta ( \kappa _U(k)).
Each family (K_U, \kappa _U), whose existence is stipulated by the previous condition, is also directed.

Our experience has shown, however, that it might not have been correct to call this notion ‚Äúbasis‚Äù. The problem is that there is a nontrivial structure involved in this definition: the index set B of the basis. Under certain favourable conditions the basis of a locale (or resp. dcpo) is uniquely determined. Because of this nontrivial structure, however, this does not work in our case.

Proposed change 1. Rename what we have been calling ‚Äúsmall basis‚Äù so far to ‚Äúbasis description‚Äù.
The idea is that there might be two different descriptions for the same basis, and it is not surprising that these are not the same. This is completely natural. The reason it seems surprising is that we called the wrong thing ‚Äúbasis‚Äù.
